employer: IRES 2025 Research Program in Lyon, France
title: Undergraduate Researcher
description: This is a research internship under Dr. Michael Niemier that took place in Lyon, France at Ãˆcole Centrale de Lyon. With four other undergraduate students, I benchmarked figures of merit for different AES hardware accelerators and developed Python files and Google Colab sessions to automatically generate graphs of desired data points. These graphs and our data was used in sponsor presentations! We additionally did some research on applying emerging memory technologies, specifically ferroelectrics, to an AES accelerator and presented a modified bitcell using 1FeFET-1C cells for the byte substitution step. Beyond research, being in France for two months was an incredible opportunity to engage with international students and a brand-new culture (and learn a bit of French).

title: Radio and Communications Lead and Club Member
description: Domer Rover is an engineering build club where our goal is to build a rover for the University Rover Competition. I served as the Radio and Communications Lead this past year, so I taught myself all about radios, earned a Technician-level Ham radio license, and developed a communication network between the rover and our base station over two frequency bands. The 900MHz band was essentially serial, so I designed a single-stream message-based weighted-round-robin communication system to accomodate this and handle any potential dips in communication. Testing showed this system works at over a kilometer distance! Check out our SAR to the right.

title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant
description: In Fall of 2024, I was a teaching assistant for Discrete Mathematics for a class of about 50 students. I held office hours once a week, coordinated with four other TAs and the instructor, and taught myself content new to this semester in order to help students. In Spring 2025, I was a grader for Magic of Numbers, a mathematics seminar for about fifteen first-year students. For Fall 2025, I will be a Fundamentals of Computing TA for second-years.

title: Conversations of Purpose Mentor
description: The Foundations of Theology class I took included a weekly conversation with members of the same dorm. I served as a co-lead for these conversations with the members of Sorin College, my university dorm, fostering conversations about theology, faith, and the ways they relate to personal life for six first-years.

title: Floater/Senior Staff
description: At Kilwins, the main ice cream and chocolate store near me, I provided friendly service, welcoming each customer at the door, offering samples of fudge, and helping them out with whatever they needed. I collaborated with my coworkers to serve lines of 100+ people for ice cream nearly every summer weekend, and I consistently worked about 25 hours/week in the summer and during all breaks. I also helped train a few new hires.
